A promising preparation method for highly active cobalt based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts supported on stabilized Al2O3 Laura Fratalocchi a Carlo Giorgio Visconti a ⁎ Luca Lietti a ⁎ Nico Fischer b Michael Claeys b a Politecnico di Milano, Dipartimento di Energia, Laboratory of Catalysis and Catalytic Processes, Via La Masa, 34, Milano 20156, Italy Politecnico di Milano Dipartimento di Energia Laboratory of Catalysis and Catalytic Processes Via La Masa, 34 Milano 20156 Italy b University of Cape Town, Department of Chemical Engineering, Catalysis Institute and c⁎change (DST-NRF Centre of Excellence in Catalysis), Private Bag X3, Rondebosch 7701, South Africa University of Cape Town Department of Chemical Engineering Catalysis Institute and c⁎change (DST-NRF Centre of Excellence in Catalysis) Private Bag X3 Rondebosch 7701 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The effectiveness of the addition of diethylene glycol (DEG) to the impregnating solution in synthesizing highly dispersed Co-based catalysts supported on stabilized alumina (Al2O3 (s)) is investigated. Both the properties and catalytic performance in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) of the material obtained using DEG (CoDEG/Al2O3 (s)) are compared with those of a catalyst with the same formulation but prepared without the addition of DEG in the impregnating solution (Co/Al2O3 (s)). When using Co-nitrate as Co-precursor, the addition of DEG leads to a very fast and exothermic decomposition of Co-nitrate into Co oxides during the calcination step. This prevents the agglomeration of Co3O4 particles, thus generating highly dispersed Co3O4 crystallites on the support. In line with the decrease of the Co3O4 crystallites size, the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is more difficult to reduce than the Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. As a result, the metallic surface of the two catalysts is very similar. Nonetheless, when tested in the FTS, the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst shows CO conversion higher than the Co/Al2O3 (s) sample. This is attributed to the high intrinsic activity (i.e. high Turnover Frequency, TOF) of the small Co0 crystallites of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. We explain this result assuming that the combustion phenomenon occurring during the fast calcination induced by the presence of DEG may generate structural defects on the catalyst surface that are beneficial for the FTS. Notably, the product distribution of CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is only slightly affected. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Cobalt catalysts Stabilized alumina Diethylene glycol Highly-active catalysts Catalyst preparation 1 Introduction Conventional Co-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts are usually prepared by using an aqueous solution of cobalt nitrate to impregnate supports with high surface areas, such as Al2O3, SiO2 and TiO2 [1]. The impregnation step is followed by drying and calcination to form Co3O4 species that are eventually reduced to active metallic Co sites during the activation step. The catalysts obtained from this procedure often show a poor concentration of active Co0 sites. This is explained by surface migration of the Co-containing particles on the support and their agglomeration and stabilization into large crystallites during the calcination step [1]. The optimization of Fischer-Tropsch catalysts, aimed at maximizing the mass specific activity in conjunction with the selectivity for long chain hydrocarbons, is of utmost importance to reduce the process costs and ultimately to increase the profitability of the process [2]. Accordingly, as a rational strategy to increase the number of active sites available for the FTS, many efforts were devoted in the last years to prepare catalysts with small Co0 crystallites [3]. In this regard, we recall that while the FTS is structure insensitive for large crystallites, a threshold value of the Co0 crystallites size exists below which a monotonic decrease of the Turnover Frequency (TOF) is observed [3–7]. Such a value, which depends on the process conditions, is around 8–10 nm under typical FTS conditions [5]. The origin of the decrease of the intrinsic specific activity with decreasing crystallite size is a longstanding scientific question. Several reports ascribe the TOF-size correlation to the fact that small Co0 particles are more prone to re-oxidation by water, the main product of the FTS [3–13]. This phenomenon occurs especially under realistic FTS conditions (high water partial pressures) [12,13], at which also the agglomeration of the cobalt species into bigger crystallites [14,15], and/or the formation of inactive cobalt-support mixed compounds can take place [9,11]. For example, with supports such as Al2O3 or SiO2, it is known that irreducible cobalt-support mixed species (i.e., cobalt aluminates or cobalt silicates) can be formed during the preparation, reduction and testing of the catalysts, especially when highly dispersed materials are used [16]. A theory based on the cobalt surface structure is also proposed to account for observed size dependencies [5]. The decrease of TOF with highly dispersed Co crystallites is related both to the blocking of abundant edge and/or corner sites by irreversible CO chemisorption and to the lower intrinsic activity at the small terraces [5]. Furthermore, the strongly bonded CO is considered responsible for a hampering of the surface reconstruction process, which is needed to form the highly active FTS sites [5]. A more detailed analysis of such geometric effects and how it impacts on various sites on fcc cobalt particles of different size was recently provided by van Helden et al. [17]. In the presence of crystallites smaller than 8–10 nm Co-based FTS catalysts also show undesired selectivity [4,18]. This is due to the fact that FTS comprises several elementary steps which require a certain arrangement of surface atoms to provide the desired performance [19,20]. For instance, an increase in the hydrogenation activity (resulting in higher CH4 formation, lower chain growth probability and lower olefin/paraffin ratio in the products) is observed with decreasing crystallites size, which is explained considering that the activation for the H2 dissociation seems to be favored over that of CO, leading a higher hydrogen to carbon ratio on the catalyst surface [20]. In line with these observations, the synthesis of Co0 nanoparticles with a diameter near 8–10 nm seems mandatory to optimize both the FTS activity and selectivity. To date, many routes were proposed to synthesize supported cobalt nanoparticles, including: (i) impregnation [21,22], (ii) homogeneous deposition-precipitation method [23], (iii) electrostatic adsorption of Co complexes on the support [24], (iv) sol-gel method [25], and (v) organic matrix combustion (OMx) method [26]. The latter procedure, which is based on the addition of an organic compound to the Co-impregnating solution, seems to be one of the most effective according to the catalyst performance claimed by Velocys [26–28]. To our knowledge, the effectiveness of the OMx method in synthesizing highly dispersed Co-based catalysts for FTS was reported mainly in combination with SiO2 supports, which are known to be weakly interacting with cobalt species [21–29]. Only a few studies were focused on γ-Al2O3 [30], a material which is also frequently employed as FTS catalyst support due to its high thermal stability. Notably, the γ-Al2O3 support strongly interacts with Co oxides particles possibly leading to the formation of Co-alumina mixed compounds which are inactive in the FTS. To prevent or minimize these interactions, additives may be added to the catalyst formulation [31]. The purpose of this study was to assess the effectiveness of the addition of an organic compound to the Co-nitrate impregnating solution for the synthesis of small Co particles supported on a γ-Al2O3 support stabilized with Co aluminates. These species act as structural stabilizers [31], which enhance the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst and, also, as electronic promoters, which weaken the interactions of active Co0 centers and Al2O3. The catalyst of this study was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) using an aqueous solution containing Co-nitrate as Co-precursor and diethylene glycol (DEG) as organic compound. Comparative characterizations and FTS performance tests were carried out by using a reference catalyst having the same formulation and prepared without adding DEG. No promoters (such as noble metals) were added to the catalyst formulation so as to understand if the presence of DEG may be enough to synthetize a FTS catalyst with activity and/or selectivity boosted compared to those prepared without using organic compounds. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The alumina support was purposefully stabilized with inactive cobalt aluminate species, following the procedure described in our recent work [31]. Briefly, γ-Al2O3 pellets (Sasol Puralox®, Dpellet = 300 μm) were impregnated (incipient wetness impregnation, IWI, method) with an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 98 wt.%) so to reach a Co loading of 5.7 wt.% (0.67 gsalt/mlsolution). Then, the sample was dried in static air at 120 °C for 1 h and calcined in static air at 900 °C for 4 h (heating rate: 1.5 °C/min). This treatment resulted in an evident color change from pink (cobalt nitrate) to blue as a consequence of the formation of cobalt aluminates (Fig. 1 ). The obtained material will be referred in the following as Al2O3 (s). Cobalt used for the support stabilization is “sacrificial” because forms species (Co-aluminates) inactive in the CO hydrogenation as verified experimentally. In order to prepare catalysts with active Co loading of around 18 wt.%, stabilized alumina was impregnated four times with an aqueous mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and diethylene glycol (DEG, Sigma Aldrich, ≥99.0%) using DEG to Co-nitrate molar ratios equal to 0 (reference catalyst) or 0.5 (0.75 gsalt/mlsolution). Each impregnation step was followed by drying in static air at 120 °C for 2 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min) and calcination in static air at 500 °C for 4 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min). In the following, the catalysts prepared with and without DEG will be referred to as CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s), respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 TG/DTA and O2-TPSR Thermogravimetric/differential thermal analyses (TG/DTA) in air and temperature programmed surface reaction in diluted oxygen (O2-TPSR) were carried out on the samples obtained after the first impregnation step, dried at room temperature for 12 h. In the following, these samples will be named as CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) and CoId/Al2O3 (s), respectively. During TG/DTA, the sample was heated in synthetic air (1833 cm3(STP)/min/gcat, Sapio) from ambient temperature to 700 °C at 2 °C/min in an Exstar 6000 instrument from Seiko Instruments. In O2-TPSR experiments, the sample was heated from 25 to 500 °C (heating rate: 10 °C/min) under a diluted O2 stream (1666 cm3(STP)/min/gcat, 2.06 vol.% O2 in He, Sapio). Obtained gas products were analysed by using an on-line quadrupole mass-spectrometer (Pfeiffer Omnistar). The following mass-to-charge ratios (m/e) were recorded: 16 (CH4), 18 (H2O), 28 (CO, N2), 30 (NO), 32 (O2), 44 (CO2) and 46 (NO2). 2.2.2 BET and ICP-MS The BET area (SBET) and the specific pore volume (Vp) of the calcined catalysts were estimated from the N2 adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K in a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. Prior to the measurements, samples were heated at 120 °C for 3 h at 0.1 Torr. The average pore size (dp) and the pore size distribution were calculated from the adsorption branch of the isotherm using the BJH method. The total amount of Co loaded on the catalysts, inclusive of the amount of cobalt used for the support stabilization, was determined by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (Thermo Electron, X series 2 ICP-MS) on the samples dissolved in ultrapure concentrated nitric acid (Sigma Aldrich, 70%). 2.2.3 H2-TPR H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analyses were carried out both on the calcined (exp a) and reduced (exp b) catalysts using a Micromeritics Thermoquest TPDRO1100 instrument. The instrument is equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) located downstream the reactor after a soda lime steam trap. In exp a the calcined sample was heated from 40 to 1050 °C (heating rate: 15 °C/min) under a flow of 5.15 vol.% H2 in Ar (600 cm3(STP)/min/gcat, Sapio). In exp b, the sample was reduced in situ at 400 °C (heating rate: 2 °C/min) for 17 h using 83 cm3(STP)/min/gcat of pure H2 (Sapio, 99.995 mol.%) and then cooled to 40 °C in Ar (Sapio, 99.999 mol.%). Then, the reactor was purged with a stream of 5.15 vol.% H2 in Ar, and further heated to 1050 °C (heating rate: 15 °C/min). H2 consumption in this latter heating step correlates with the amount of cobalt which remains unreduced after the treatment in H2 at 400 °C. The extent of reduction (EORTPR, [%]) from Co3O4 to Co0 was calculated by applying Eq. (1): (1) E O R T P R [ % ] = ( 1 - n H 2 r e d n H 2 c a l ) ∙ 100 where n H 2 r e d is the amount of H2 consumed during the TPR analysis of the reduced catalyst (exp b) and n H 2 c a l is the amount of H2 consumed during the TPR analysis of the calcined catalyst (exp a). 2.2.4 In-situ XRD XRD measurements were carried out with an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advanced) equipped with a Co-Kα radiation source (λ = 1.78897 Å) and a position sensitive detector (VÅNTEC-2000, Bruker AXS). The in-situ XRD reaction cell developed at the University of Cape Town was used in these experiments [32,33]. The sample (15 mg) was placed in a borosilicate capillary reactor with a 1 mm outer diameter and 0.01 mm wall thickness (Hilgenberg GmbH, Germany). Then, it was exposed to a H2 gas stream of 5000 cm3(STP)/h/gcat (Afrox, 99.999 mol.%) at atmospheric pressure and 400 °C for 17 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min). The temperature of the bed was directly monitored via an internally mounted thermocouple, while the reactor was heated with two infrared heaters (Elstein MSH) in series. The powder diffractograms of both the calcined (before the reduction treatment, T.o.R. = 0 h) and reduced (at the end of the reduction process, T.o.R. ≈ 20 h) catalysts were collected over a 2θ range of 20–120° at a scan time of 1 s/step. The powder diffraction patterns during the whole in-situ reduction process were collected over a narrower 2θ range of 40–62° at a scan time of 0.5 s/step (step size of 0.0616°), so as to minimize the time required to perform each scan and to maximize temporal resolution. The observed reflexes were identified based on entries in the International Centre for Diffraction Data PDF-2 database. XRD patterns were analyzed with full pattern fitting via the Rietveld refinement approach using the TOPAS 4.1 software (Bruker AXS) to determine crystallite sizes and composition of the cobalt phase of the catalysts. The Sasol Puralox® Al2O3 material used in this work has an unknown crystal structure and hence it was not considered in the refinement. Its reflexes were described as two distinct peaks at 53.71 and 79.47° modeled according to the fundamental parameters profile function. Accordingly, the quantitative results are normalized to the sum of Co°, CoO, Co3O4 and CoAl2O4. 2.2.5 In-situ magnetic measurements The reduction of the catalysts at 400 °C for 17 h (heating rate: 2 °C/min) in H2 (5000 cm3(STP)/h/gcat, Afrox, 99.999 mol.%) at atmospheric pressure was also studied using the in situ magnetometer developed by Claeys et al. in collaboration of the University of Cape Town and Sasol [34]. The reactor consists of a 1/2” stainless steel tube with a non-magnetic brass frit to support the catalyst bed. A non-magnetic temperature detector (Pt100 RTD) is placed with the tip in the bed while two infrared heaters supply uniform heat the reactor. The setup is based on the Weiss extraction method, and uses a field-controlled electromagnet that provides field strengths up to 20 kOe. This instrument allows monitoring the amount of metallic cobalt, i.e. the only ferromagnetic phase present, and therefore the degree of reduction of the catalyst during the entire activation step. In addition, magnetic measurements can give insight on the Co0 particle size distribution if the crystallites present in the catalyst are mostly relatively small and therefore display superparamagnetic behavior. A description of the set-up and examples of its use can be found in [12,14,34]. The degree of reduction of the catalysts ( D O R m a g n e t % ) was estimated using Eq. (2): (2) D O R m a g n e t % = g C o e x p g C o t o t - g C o C o A l 2 O 4 ∙ 100 where g C o e x p is the amount of metallic cobalt in the sample, which can be quantified from the saturation magnetization (Ms measured at 20 kOe) after calibration of the instrument with known amounts of magnetic material [14], g C o t o t is the total amount of cobalt in the sample and g C o C o A l 2 O 4 is the amount of cobalt used for the support stabilization. A full M-H curve from −20 to 20 kOe was also measured at 400 °C on the reduced catalysts under Ar flow (Afrox, 99.999 mol.%). By fitting Langevin functions, this test allows obtaining a crystallite size distribution of the superparamagnetic Co0 nanoparticles [12]. However, the Langevin function can only be applied with samples containing predominantly superparamagnetic crystallites, i.e. a very low amount of larger crystallites which display remnant magnetization upon the removal of an external field (γ < 10%). The γ value was calculated from the saturation magnetization (Ms) and the remnant magnetization (Mr) measured at 20 and 0 kOe respectively (Eq. (3)): (3) γ [ w t . % ] = 200 ∙ M r M s 2.2.6 H2-chemisorption Information on the Co0 dispersion of the catalysts was collected running H2-chemisorption experiments using the same TPDRO instrument which was used to run TPR experiments. To this end, 300 mg of sample were placed in a quartz reactor and reduced in situ at 400 °C (heating rate: 2 °C/min) and atmospheric pressure for 17 h under a flow of pure H2 (5000 cm3(STP)/h/gcat, Sapio, 99.995 mol.%). After flowing Ar (Sapio, 99.999 mol.%) at 400 °C and atmospheric pressure for 2 h and cooling to 100 °C, successive pulses of H2 (264 μL/pulse) were passed over the catalyst. The total amount of chemisorbed hydrogen ( m o l H 2 c h e m i ) was calculated from the difference between the peak area obtained during the saturation experiment and the areas of the peaks in the absence of a chemisorption event. Then, by assuming a chemisorption stoichiometry of Co:H equal to 1, the cobalt metal dispersion (D, [%]) was calculated as per Eq. (4). (4) D % = m o l H 2 c h e m i ∙ 2 m o l C o t o t ∙ D O R m a g n e t ∙ 100 where m o l H 2 c h e m i is the total amount of H2 chemisorbed in the experiment and m o l C o t o t is the amount of active cobalt loaded on the catalysts. The average cobalt metal crystallite size ( d C o c h e m i 0 ) was also estimated using Eq. (5) [35]: (5) d C o c h e m i 0 [ n m ] = 96 D [ % ] 2.3 Catalytic tests CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s) catalysts were tested in the FTS using a fixed bed tubular reactor (1.1 cm ID) after dilution with α-Al2O3 pellets of the same granulometry so as to prevent local hot-spots (catalyst: alumina = 1:4, v/v). More details on the reactor and on the used lab-scale apparatus can be found in [36] and references therein. In order to activate the catalysts, the samples were reduced in situ in H2 (Sapio, 99.995 mol.%) at 400 °C (heating rate = 2 °C/min) and atmospheric pressure for 17 h at a space velocity of 5000 cm3(STP)/h/gcat. Catalytic runs were carried out at relevant process conditions: T = 200 °C, P = 25 bar, H2/CO inlet molar ratio = 2.0, GHSV = 6410 cm3(STP)/h/gcat, inerts (N2+ Ar) in the feed = 24 vol.%. The unconverted reactants and the full spectrum of products were measured by on-line and off-line gas-chromatography. Details on the product collection and analysis procedures can be found elsewhere [37]. In order to collect representative activity data, both the catalysts studied in this work were tested for more than 90 h. In order to check the achievement of steady state conditions, multiple data at the same experimental condition were collected for more than 48 consecutive hours. Data were considered steady when the CO conversion ( X C O % , Eq. (6)) and the selectivity to the main FTS products ( S i % , Eq. (7)) varied within less than 5% in 48 h. (6) X C O [ % ] = ( 1 - F C O o u t F C O i n ) ⋅ 100 (7) S i % = F i o u t ∙ n i ∑ i N P ( F i o u t ∙ n i ) + F C O 2 o u t ∙ 100 F i o u t is the molar productivity of ith hydrocarbon species, n i is the carbon atom number of the ith species and NP is the number of the hydrocarbon products (paraffins C1–C49 and olefins C2–C17) identified at the reactor outlet. The selectivity to carbon dioxide was calculated as in Eq. (8): (8) S C O 2 % = F C O 2 o u t F C O i n - F C O o u t ∙ 100 The standard deviations of the selectivity values to CO2, CH4 and C5+ are around 0.1, 0.4 and 1%, respectively. Furthermore, carbon balances, calculated as moles of C contained in the reaction products divided by the moles of CO converted, always closed within ±5%. The intrinsic catalytic activity (turnover frequency, TOF) was also calculated as in Eq. (9): (9) T O F [ s - 1 ] = r C O 0 2 ∙ m o l H 2 c h e m i where r C O 0 is the CO consumption rate [mol/s/gcat] estimated at the reactor inlet by using the rate expression (Eq. (10)) proposed by Zennaro et al. [38]: (10) r C O = k T P C O - 0.24 P H 2 0.74 This rate law, which was obtained using data collected at low CO conversion with a Co/TiO2 catalyst, was proven to be appropriate to describe also the CO consumption rate at higher CO conversion levels and with Co/Al2O3 catalysts [39]. An isothermal pseudo-homogeneous plug-flow reactor model was adopted for the estimation of the kinetic constant k ( T ) . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) and CoId/Al2O3 (s) dried samples The results of thermal gravimetric (TG/DTG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) in air of CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) and CoId/Al2O3 (s) samples are shown in Fig. 2 . In the case of the CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) sample (Fig. 2(a)), a weight loss (near 23%) is observed in the 25–120 °C T-range due to the loss of water. Then, the DTA curve shows a sharp peak at 160 °C indicating a very fast and exothermic reaction associated with a weight loss of 7.5%. A less intense peak is also detected in the 210–260 °C temperature range, indicating a slower exothermic reaction to which a further weight loss of 8.4% is associated. No phenomena are detected at temperatures over 260 °C. The results obtained with the CoId/Al2O3 (s) sample are shown in Fig. 2(b). Weight losses (≈22%) are seen in the 25–120 °C T-range, again due to the loss of water, and in the 120–300 °C T-range (≈13%). The latter is associated with a nearly athermic process. In order to gain more insight into the phenomena occurring during calcination, O2-TPSR experiments were also carried out on the two dried samples and results are shown in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3(a), which refers to the CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) sample, shows that the signal of H2O increases from room temperature until a maximum is reached at 85 °C, confirming sample dehydration in the 25–120 °C T-range. The evolution of NO is also evident with a maximum at 168 °C and a shoulder at 197 °C. Both these peaks are attributed to the decomposition of Co nitrate into Co oxides. The maximum of the NO signal at 168 °C can be associated with the first peak observed in the DTA analysis at 160 °C (Fig. 2(a)) representative of an exothermic reaction. This suggests the occurrence of a reaction between Co-nitrate and DEG, leading to H2O and NOx evolution along with a minor amount of CO2, which is also detected among the reaction products. However, this does not lead to a complete consumption of DEG, which is indeed oxidized by O2 at temperatures above 200 °C, as shown by O2 consumption and a corresponding evolution of water and CO2. Accordingly, the two exothermic processes detected by TG/DTA on this sample may be associated with the oxidation of DEG by nitrate (fast process) and by oxygen (slower process), respectively. In the case of the CoId/Al2O3 (s) sample (Fig. 3(b)), the decomposition from Co nitrate to Co oxides species is observed at higher temperatures and occurs at a slower rate if compared to the CoDEGId/Al2O3 (s) sample. Also, no O2 is consumed, thus indicating that cobalt nitrate evolves into cobalt oxide via endothermic decomposition. Notably, these results are well in line with TG/DTG and DTA findings previously discussed. These observations are a clear evidence that the addition of diethylene glycol in the Co impregnating solution introduces a different and faster route for the conversion of Co nitrate to Co oxides. Due to the presence of DEG, which effectively acts as fuel in the combustion of Co-nitrate, Co-nitrate decomposition to Co-oxides becomes very fast and strongly exothermic. 3.2 Characterization of Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) calcined catalysts 3.2.1 BET and ICP-MS analyses The textural properties of the γ-Al2O3 pellets and the stabilized Al2O3 (s) are shown in Table 1 with those of the calcined catalysts Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s). The textural properties of support pellets after calcination at 900 °C (following the same procedure adopted to manufacture the Al2O3 (s) sample) are also reported in Table 1 for comparison purposes (sample named γ-Al2O3 (900 °C)). Both BET area and pore volume of the stabilized alumina are about 30% lower than those of the starting γ-Al2O3 pellets. Notably, these values are similar to those obtained with the γ-Al2O3 (900 °C) sample, thus suggesting that the decrease of the textural properties in Al2O3 (s) support depends on the high-temperature stabilization procedure. The further decrease of the pore volume (from 0.41 cm3/g of γ-Al2O3 (900 °C) to 0.37 cm3/g of Al2O3 (s)) is due to the Co impregnation. In the catalysts the values are almost half compared to those of the Al2O3 (s) support. The BJH pore diameter is similar for the stabilized support and catalysts. The pore size distributions (not shown) show a narrow pore size distribution in the mesopore range (Table 1). The actual Co loading of the catalysts obtained by ICP-MS analyses, which is inclusive of both the active cobalt and the cobalt used for support stabilization, is in good agreement with the target value (Table 1). These results indicate that combustion phenomena occurring during the calcination steps of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst cause neither a significant change in the textural properties nor a loss of active phase. 3.2.2 XRD analyses Fig. 4 (a) shows the diffraction patterns of γ-Al2O3 powder and γ-Al2O3 (900 °C) sample. The diffraction patterns are similar, thus indicating that the γ- phase is still dominant in the Al2O3 support even after the high-temperature calcination. New peaks can be also detected at 2θ : 38.2, 40.5, 54.5 and 59.6° on this sample. These peaks are representative of a mixture of θ and δ-Al2O3 phases, which are hardly distinguishable considering the low amount. No peaks representative of the α-phase are detected. Fig. 4(b) shows the diffraction patterns of γ-Al2O3 powder, Al2O3 (s) support and the two catalysts. The calcination at 900 °C used for the preparation of Al2O3 (s) pellets causes the interaction of cobalt-containing species with the support, resulting in the formation of cobalt aluminates (main peaks at 36.4 and 42.9°) whose diffraction peaks overlap with those of Co3O4. XRD patterns of the calcined CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s) catalysts show crystalline phases associated with Co3O4, CoAl2O4 and γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 4). Nevertheless, different average Co3O4 crystallite sizes are obtained via Rietveld refinement (Table 2 ), i.e., 21 nm for the Co/Al2O3 (s) and 10 nm for the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s). Accordingly, the addition of DEG in the Co-nitrate impregnating solution leads to smaller Co oxides onto the catalytic surface. This is probably related either to the very fast and exothermic decomposition of Co-nitrate during calcination in the presence of DEG, which prevents the agglomeration of Co3O4 crystallites, or to the catalytic combustion of residual DEG at high calcination temperature, which causes the segregation of Co3O4 species (Figs. 2 and 3(a)). The changes in Co crystalline phases as observed during the in-situ reduction process in the XRD cell (400 °C, heating rate: 2 °C/min, 17 h holding time) in the presence of pure H2 are shown in Fig. 5 . Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 phases are detected from 25 °C to 200 °C, thus indicating that the catalysts reduction has not started yet. A rapid change from Co3O4 to CoO is observed at 220 °C and 240 °C for CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s), respectively (Fig. 5(a) and (c)). The reduction from Co3+ to Co2+ is completed at 310 °C for both samples. The reduction from CoO to Co0 starts at 330 °C in the case of Co/Al2O3 (s), but only at 400 °C in the sample prepared with DEG (Fig. 5(d)). In this regard, both catalysts contain a purely fcc metallic cobalt phase. The reduction phenomenon slowly proceeds for at least 7 h for both catalysts. At the end of the reduction process, the amount of Co0 fcc in Co/Al2O3 (s) is higher than in CoDEG/Al2O3 (s). Interestingly, the amount of CoAl2O4 species initially present on both catalysts does not change during the reduction process (Fig. 5(b)). This can be related to the stability of this support. Fig. 6 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced catalysts. The average Co0 crystallite sizes obtained via Rietveld refinement are 14 nm and 9 nm for Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s), respectively (Table 2). Notably, even though the Co0 formation strongly increases with T.o.R, the average Co0 size is almost constant during the whole reduction process with both the catalysts. 3.2.3 Magnetic measurements As a first step, magnetic measurements were used to assess the reducibility of the Al2O3 (s) support during the H2 treatment at 400 °C for 17 h. A degree of reduction below 1% was found for the sample, thus indicating that CoAl2O4 species are not reducible at the adopted activation conditions. These results are in good agreement with those obtained with in-situ XRD analyses, and in particular those indicating the stability of CoAl2O4 species during the reduction process (Fig. 5(b)). This result also rationalizes the non-reactivity of the Al2O3 (s) support at FTS conditions. The degree of reduction of the catalysts (DORmagnet, Eq. (2)), monitored during the entire catalyst activation step through in-situ magnetic measurements, is shown in Fig. 7 . The transformation from non-ferromagnetic cobalt oxides (both Co3O4 and CoO) to ferromagnetic metallic cobalt starts at around 320 °C and 400 °C in Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalysts, respectively and slowly proceeds during the 17 h at 400 °C. Notably, the appearance of Co0 species is observed at temperatures similar to those obtained with in-situ XRD. At the end of the catalyst activation process, DORmagnet is 19 and 37% for the catalysts prepared with and without DEG, respectively (Fig. 7). Fig. 8 shows the magnetization of the reduced catalysts as function of the field strength (−20 to 20 kOe). With both catalysts magnetic hysteresis behavior is observed. In line with XRD findings, the remnant magnetization and the coercive force obtained with Co-DEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst are clearly smaller and closer to zero than in Co/Al2O3 (s), thus indicating that the catalyst prepared with DEG has a smaller percentage of large crystallites, and therefore likely a particle size distribution centered around lower values compared to the catalyst which was prepared without DEG. Unfortunately, more accurate information about the Co0 particle size distribution cannot be obtained because the values of γ are 18 and 50 wt.%, respectively, for Co-DEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s). 3.2.4 H2-TPR analyses The results obtained from H2-TPR measurements performed on the calcined catalysts (exp (a)) are shown in Fig. 9 (a and b). By using Gaussian fitting, four distinct reduction peaks can be identified in the TPR profile of both catalysts. In the case of the calcined Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (Fig. 9(a)), the small first peak with a maximum at 272 °C is associated with the reduction of cobalt nitrates. The presence of residual Co(NO3)2 in calcined cobalt based catalysts is reported in literature [40] and its presence is shown to depend on both the duration and the temperature applied for the calcination step. The following two peaks with maxima at 370 and 598 °C are associated with the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and of CoO to metallic Co, (as confirmed by in-situ XRD measurements). Eventually, the last peak with a maximum at 992 °C involves the reduction of Cox+ species highly interacting with the support. These latter may be the CoAl2O4 species used for the support stabilization, as suggested by the TPR profile of Al2O3 (s) reported in [31], and/or the Co-Al mixed species formed during H2-TPR via interaction at high temperature (>800 °C) of partially reduced Co-species (likely CoO) and the support. In the case of the calcined CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) (Fig. 9(b)), Co(NO3)2 reduction peak is hardly detectable (small shoulder at 288 °C), in line with the easier decomposition of Co-nitrate in the presence of DEG (see O2-TPSR experiments in Fig. 3). The peak with a maximum at 372 °C is related to Co3O4 to CoO reduction, while the following peaks with maxima at 550 °C and 708 °C, respectively, are both believed to be associated with the reduction of CoO particles to Co0. In particular, the first peak is possibly due to the reduction of the largest CoO particles, which is known to occur at lower temperature than in the case of smaller particles. The peak with a maximum at 958 °C is related to the reduction of CoAl2O4 species. The area of such a peak is larger than the area of the corresponding peak in Fig. 9(a). In consideration of the fact that the two catalysts have the same content of CoAl2O4 species before the TPR, this is a clear indication that more CoAl2O4 species are formed during the TPR analysis in the case of the catalyst with the smallest Co crystallites. TPR data confirm that Co3O4 species present on the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) are significantly harder to reduce than on the Co/Al2O3 (s). Particularly, significant is the difference between the temperature of the Co2+ to Co0 reduction peak, which is shifted to higher T-values for the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (maximum recorded at 708 °C instead of 598 °C). However, the temperature of the maximum of the Co3+ to  Co2+ reduction peak is almost identical in Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalysts. This result is in line with literature information showing that the reduction step from CoO to Co0 is strongly particle size-dependent [35]. The TPR profiles of reduced catalysts (exp (b)) are shown in Fig. 9(c and d). The peak assigned to the Co3+ → Co2+ reduction completely disappears in both samples, indicating that residual Co3O4 species are not present in both catalysts after a reduction treatment at 400 °C in pure H2 for 17 h. On the contrary, CoO to Co0 reduction peaks are still partially present in both catalysts, indicating an incomplete reduction of the samples, especially for the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s). Indeed, an extent of reduction (EORTPR, Eq. (1)) of 39% can be calculated for the Co/Al2O3 (s), while a value of 23% is found for the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) (Table 2). Notably, these results well agree with those obtained with in-situ XRD and in-situ magnetic measurements (DORmagnet, Table 2). In the TPR profiles of the reduced catalysts (exp b) (Fig. 9(c and d)), the peaks observed at high temperature associated with the reduction of Co-aluminates match closely with those observed in the TPR profiles of the calcined catalysts (exp a) (Fig. 9(a and b)). This suggests that the cobalt species interacting with the support “survive” the 17 h reduction in H2 at 400 °C. However, the interactions between the support and cobalt occur only at the high temperatures reached during H2-TPR and cannot take place either during the catalyst activation step, as demonstrated by in-situ XRD analyses (Fig. 5(b)), or during FTS runs [31]. 3.2.5 H2 chemisorption analyses The total amounts of adsorbed hydrogen measured during H2 chemisorption tests (Table 2) carried out on the two reduced catalysts are similar, thus suggesting a similar number of active cobalt metal surface sites. However, the Co0 dispersion calculated by taking into account the different reducibility of the samples (D, Eq. (4)) is 6.5 and 11.1% for Co/Al2O3 (s) and CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalysts, respectively (Table 2). This is due to the fact that the Co0 dispersion depends on the dispersion of the starting Co3O4 species (size of the Co3O4 crystallites) and reducibility thereof. The fact that the catalysts have similar amounts of adsorbed hydrogen is a coincidence and indicates that the two parameters dispersion and reducibility are “balanced” in the two catalysts. Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst has higher degree of reduction but lower Co3O4 dispersion/larger crystallites, while CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst has lower degree of reduction but higher Co3O4 dispersion/smaller crystallites. An average Co metal particles size of 8.7 nm and 15 nm is calculated for CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s) catalysts, respectively (Eq. (5)). Notably, these values well match those obtained via in-situ XRD analysis (Table 2). 3.3 Morphology of reduced Co/Al2O3 and CoDEG/Al2O3 catalysts A sketch of what happens during the reduction of the calcined Co/Al2O3 and CoDEG/Al2O3 catalysts is shown in Fig. 10 . This sketch is based on the evidence that the average cobalt particles size (in-situ XRD analysis) remains constant during reduction, thus suggesting that the reduction does not proceed via a shrinking-core model with the CoO particles having a Co0 shell. As a consequence of the very fast and exothermic decomposition of Co-nitrate during calcination, the average Co3O4 crystallites size (in-situ XRD analysis) of the calcined CoDEG/Al2O3 catalyst is almost halved if compared to that of the Co/Al2O3 sample. At the same time, as shown by in-situ magnetic measurements, the Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is more easily reducible than the CoDEG/Al2O3 sample at the adopted activation conditions. However, on both the samples, the Co3O4 species are fully converted to CoO. Accordingly, on the reduced catalysts, the amount of unreduced CoO species is higher in the CoDEG/Al2O3 sample than in the Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (in-situ XRD and TPR analyses). This is in line with the fact that the catalyst reducibility is facilitated in the presence of large cobalt oxides particles. Also, the average Co0 crystallites size of the CoDEG/Al2O3 catalyst is significantly lower than that of the Co/Al2O3 sample (in-situ XRD analysis). However, the number of active Co0 sites (as determined by H2 chemisorption) is similar. Accordingly, the reduced CoDEG/Al2O3 sample can be sketched as characterized by a larger number of smaller CoO and Co0 crystallites compared to the Co/Al2O3 catalyst so that the final metal surface of the two catalysts is very similar (Fig. 10). 3.4 Catalyst testing The catalysts were found to be very stable with Time on Stream (T.o.S.), both in terms of activity and selectivity (Table 3 ). This is particularly relevant for CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst, with its small Co0 crystallites that are often considered as unstable and prone to deactivation [4]. We speculate that the high stability of our catalysts is due to the support stabilization. Fig. 11 shows the steady-state CO conversion values (Eq. (6)) measured with CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s) catalysts at 200 °C, 25 bar, H2/CO inlet molar ratio = 2.0, GHSV = 6410 cm3(STP)/h/gcat, inerts (N2+Ar) in the feed = 24 vol.% after around 90 h on stream. The selectivities to methane, carbon dioxide, C5+ and C25+ hydrocarbons are also shown (Eqs. (7) and (8)). CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) shows a much higher conversion of CO than Co/Al2O3 (s) (31% instead of 20%). Due to the fact that minor differences are obtained in terms of number of Co0 sites among the two catalysts, the higher CO conversion of the catalyst prepared using DEG can be explained with the fact that its Co0 centers are intrinsically more active. As a matter of fact, the turnover frequency (Eq. (9) of CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) results almost doubled (94·10−3 s−1) compared to that of Co/Al2O3 (s) (52·10−3 s-1). It is speculated that the higher TOF of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) sample is due to the fact that the combustion phenomena occurring during the fast calcination induced by the presence of DEG may cause structural defects that are beneficial for the FTS [41]. An alternative explanation is given by the fact that the H2-dissociation is more favored than that of CO over small crystallites, thus resulting in an increase of the H-coverage at the catalytic surface at the expense of CO [20, 42, 43]. This in turn boosts the kinetics of the FTS, i.e. the CO conversion rate. In order to compare the performance of our catalysts with the data reported in literature under similar process conditions (T = 205–210 °C, H2/CO = 2 mol/mol and P = 20, 25 and 35 bar) [4,44–46], the TOF values of the two catalysts were also calculated by running tests at 210 °C. As shown in Fig. 12 , the values of TOF reported in literature at process conditions similar to those adopted in our work are in the range of 20–100·10−3 s−1 for Co particle size larger than 8 nm [4,44,46]. Considerable deviations are only observed for the catalyst developed by Velocys [45], which was prepared via the OMx method (TOF of 200·10−3 s−1) and for one of the catalysts reported by Logdberg et al. [44], which was prepared by a micro emulsion technique (TOF of 136·10−3 s−1). Interestingly, while the TOF value of our Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (85·10−3 s−1) is well aligned to that of the majority of Co-based FT catalysts (TOF-size plateau), that of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (131·10−3 s−1) is located in an intermediate position between these catalysts and that claimed by Velocys [45]. Looking at products pool, while the selectivity to carbon dioxide (<0.3%) is negligible for both catalysts (Fig. 11), CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) shows a slightly higher methane selectivity (10% instead of 8%) and slightly lower C5+ and C25+ selectivities compared to the Co/Al2O3 (s) ( S C 5 + C o - D E G = 77% and S C 25 + C o - D E G = 20% vs. S C 5 + C o = 79% and S C 25 + C o = 21%) (Fig. 11). This is well evident also in the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) plots shown in Fig. 13 . Both distributions show the typical positive and negative deviations from the ideal linear distribution for methane and C2 hydrocarbons, respectively, and a change of slope at a carbon number around 8. Only, a slightly higher CH4 selectivity of CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) is evident, which results in a slightly smaller chain growth probability for the C15+ species (αC15+ = 0.894 and 0.896 for CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) and Co/Al2O3 (s), respectively). These results go in the same direction of previous studies showing an increase of the methane selectivity by decreasing the metal crystallite size and the inverse trend for the C5+ selectivity, which usually decreases correspondingly [4,18]. As a result of the combined effects on the CO conversion and on the hydrocarbon product distribution, CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) shows an overall C5+ yield higher than Co/Al2O3 (s) (24% instead of 15%), thus indicating that the increase of intrinsic activity caused by the adoption of DEG during the preparation far outweighs the slight negative effect on C5+ selectivity. The CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is also characterized by a lower selectivity to unsaturated hydrocarbons compared to the Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst (Fig. 11). This is further shown in Fig. 14 , where the olefin to paraffin ratio (O/P) is plotted as a function of the carbon number for both catalysts. The small selectivity changes can be explained considering that the higher concentration of hydrogen over the smaller crystallites enhances the hydrogenation of the carbon containing species thus boosting methane formation, hindering the chain growth mechanism and enhancing the secondary hydrogenation of olefins to the corresponding paraffins [42,43]. 4 Conclusions A Co-based Fischer-Tropsch catalyst was prepared by adding diethylene glycol in the impregnating aqueous solution containing the dissolved Co-nitrate salt. Due to the occurrence of combustion phenomena between Co nitrate, which acts as oxidizers, and DEG, which acts as fuel, the conversion of Co nitrate to Co oxide species during calcination becomes exothermic and fast. In contrast to a catalyst prepared in the absence of DEG, this generates highly dispersed Co oxide particles, which are however more difficult to reduce. As a result of these opposing effects, the catalysts prepared with and without DEG shows similar amounts of Co metallic sites. Notably, the catalyst prepared with DEG shows enhanced catalytic performance in terms of CO conversion rate. As matter of facts, the TOF obtained with this catalyst is higher than that obtained with the sample prepared without DEG. It is speculated that the combustion phenomenon occurring during the fast calcination induced by the presence of DEG generates structural defects on the catalyst surface that are beneficial for the FTS. Alternatively, it is suggested that the H2-dissociation is favored over CO-adsorption on small Co0 crystallites, thus boosting the kinetics of the FTS. This latter explanation is also in line with the observed effects on the product distribution, showing a minor decrease of both the O/P ratio in the products and in the chain growth probability in the case of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) sample. However, the increase in the CO conversion overcompensate for the decrease in the C5+ selectivity, thus boosting the C5+ yields. We believe that the improvement of the catalyst reducibility with the addition of a promoter (such as Pt or Re) in the catalyst formulation may overcome the “bottleneck” of CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst, thus granting a further step forward towards optimal FTS catalyst design. coredata.dc:description: The effectiveness of the addition of diethylene glycol (DEG) to the impregnating solution in synthesizing highly dispersed Co-based catalysts supported on stabilized alumina (Al2O3 (s)) is investigated. Both the properties and catalytic performance in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) of the material obtained using DEG (CoDEG/Al2O3 (s)) are compared with those of a catalyst with the same formulation but prepared without the addition of DEG in the impregnating solution (Co/Al2O3 (s)). When using Co-nitrate as Co-precursor, the addition of DEG leads to a very fast and exothermic decomposition of Co-nitrate into Co oxides during the calcination step. This prevents the agglomeration of Co3O4 particles, thus generating highly dispersed Co3O4 crystallites on the support. In line with the decrease of the Co3O4 crystallites size, the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is more difficult to reduce than the Co/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. As a result, the metallic surface of the two catalysts is very similar. Nonetheless, when tested in the FTS, the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst shows CO conversion higher than the Co/Al2O3 (s) sample. This is attributed to the high intrinsic activity (i.e. high Turnover Frequency, TOF) of the small Co0 crystallites of the CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst. We explain this result assuming that the combustion phenomenon occurring during the fast calcination induced by the presence of DEG may generate structural defects on the catalyst surface that are beneficial for the FTS. Notably, the product distribution of CoDEG/Al2O3 (s) catalyst is only slightly affected.
coredata.dc:title: A promising preparation method for highly active cobalt based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts supported on stabilized Al2O3
